eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.engines

Class CommunicationEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.engines.CommunicationEngine
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    XmppMessageEngine

    public abstract class CommunicationEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class provides a little more than an interface for specific communication engines used by OGWAPI. By extending this class a new communication engine can be implemented. Keep in mind, that any new engine that is about to be used should be reliable and secure. Usage of protocols that are open source and evidently suitable for IoT communication is encouraged (reference XMPP message engine based on Ignite Realtime's SMACK library can be found in XmppMessageEngine. Also try not to make the engine too resource hungry. Each ConnectionDescriptor has its own instance of the engine. What will happen if 100 objects will be connected through this gateway? Think big. Try to make it as optimised as possible. It is recommended to create a separate package for your new engine in eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.engines.{protocol} and put there classes that you need to support the engine. It is also advised to use some common parameters from the configuration file (those in 'general' section) before making a section of your own with additional parameters. You'd also like to add your new engine into the list of available engines in the configuration file and add it into ConnectionDescriptor's constructor decision tree in order to be loaded. In order for your engine to work, you'll of course need to implement all methods mentioned here. They will be called by the ConnectionDescriptor during various phases of the OGWAPI operation. The respective requirements are described in each method's JavaDoc. Maybe you'll find out that the methods here are not sufficient for your engine to function properly and that a new method needs to be created. This is discouraged, because nobody likes refactoring :) Try to do it without it first and only add it as a last option. Lastly, you might have noticed that there is a ConnectionDescriptor included as a field in this class (and therefore also in the class of your new engine). If you wonder what is the purpose of this field, look no further: this is how incoming message gets transferred into the ConnectionDescriptor for the current object for processing. Any time your communication engine receives a new message intended for the object that owns the ConnectionDescriptor (and therefore a particular instance of your engine), it needs to call processIncommingMessage method, with the source object ID and the message itself.
    Author:
    sulfo

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected org.apache.commons.configuration2.XMLConfiguration config
      Configuration of the OGWAPI.
      protected ConnectionDescriptor connectionDescriptor
      This ConnectionDescriptor provides access to a processIncommingMessage method.
      protected java.util.logging.Logger logger
      Logger of the OGWAPI.
      protected java.lang.String objectId
      String with the object ID that connects via this engine.
      protected java.lang.String password
      Password string for authentication.

    • Constructor Detail

      • CommunicationEngine

        public CommunicationEngine(java.lang.String objectId,
                           java.lang.String password,
                           org.apache.commons.configuration2.XMLConfiguration config,
                           java.util.logging.Logger logger,
                           ConnectionDescriptor connectionDescriptor)
        Constructor for field initialisation. Your implementation needs to call the super(objectId, password, config, logger, connectionDescriptor) method of this class as the first thing it ever does.
        Parameters:
        objectId - String with the object ID that connects via this engine.
        password - Password string for authentication.
        config - Configuration of the OGWAPI.
        logger - Logger of the OGWAPI.
        connectionDescriptor - Connection descriptor that is using this particular instance of engine.

    • Method Detail

      • connect

        public abstract boolean connect()
        This method will attempt to establish a connection with the network. The connection must be able to be closed and re-opened without a need to throw this object into a garbage collector and creating a new one.
        Returns:
        True if the connection attempt was successful, false otherwise.

      • disconnect

        public abstract void disconnect()
        This method will disconnect from the network. No contact of the network with the engine should be possible and all objects on the network should see the current object as offline. On the other hand, it should not prevent the object from reestablishing connection by using connect method without re-creating the instance of your engine.

      • isConnected

        public abstract boolean isConnected()
        Serves as a check whether or not the owner object is connected to the network or not.
        Returns:
        True if connected, false otherwise.

      • getRoster

        public abstract java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getRoster()
        Serves to retrieve a set of object IDs that are visible to the owner object.
        Returns:
        Set of object IDs visible to the object.

      • sendMessage

        public abstract boolean sendMessage(java.lang.String destinationObjectId,
                                    java.lang.String message)
        Sends a message string to a destination object identified by an ID.
        Parameters:
        destinationObjectId - Destination object ID.
        message - Message string to be sent.
        Returns:
        True if the sending of message was successful, false otherwise.
